sources.full: The Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things

deck.name: Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)
entries: The 5e {@item deck of many things} is a fantastic item with powerful magic. It can change your game in an instant, for better or worse. Each card drawn from the deck immediately impacts the character who draws from it, and in some cases, it can reshape reality itself.

You can use either the Overworld or Underworld half of the deck to represent this item in your games as a fun interactive tool for players. They can draw from the deck when they declare that their character will, or the Game Master (GM) can draw for them if you are playing online. The Overworld effects of the cards detailed in this booklet are the standard effects of the deck of many things.

However, the Fablemaker's deck of many things offers another way to play, bringing more risk and potentially more rewards than ever. The Underworld effects are an alternate version of the deck of many things. There are several ways to include these new effects in your game. You can choose to use only the Underworld effects of the cards, or you can flip a coin to determine whether the effect of a drawn card is the standard Overworld effect or the new Underworld effect. You can also shuffle both halves together and let the luck of the draw determine the effect by applying the effect matching the card drawn. For even more customization, you can select the cards you want from the Overworld and Underworld and combine them into your own unique deck of many things.

deck.name: Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)
entries: The 5e {@item deck of many things} is a fantastic item with powerful magic. It can change your game in an instant, for better or worse. Each card drawn from the deck immediately impacts the character who draws from it, and in some cases, it can reshape reality itself.

You can use either the Overworld or Underworld half of the deck to represent this item in your games as a fun interactive tool for players. They can draw from the deck when they declare that their character will, or the Game Master (GM) can draw for them if you are playing online. The Overworld effects of the cards detailed in this booklet are the standard effects of the deck of many things.

However, the Fablemaker's deck of many things offers another way to play, bringing more risk and potentially more rewards than ever. The Underworld effects are an alternate version of the deck of many things. There are several ways to include these new effects in your game. You can choose to use only the Underworld effects of the cards, or you can flip a coin to determine whether the effect of a drawn card is the standard Overworld effect or the new Underworld effect. You can also shuffle both halves together and let the luck of the draw determine the effect by applying the effect matching the card drawn. For even more customization, you can select the cards you want from the Overworld and Underworld and combine them into your own unique deck of many things.

deck.name: Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Oracle Readings)
entries: To consult the deck as an oracle, choose a problem, situation, or question in your life that you want to consider more deeply.
Shuffle both the Overworld and Underworld cards together and draw a card. Examine the imagery. How does it make you feel? Are there any symbols that resonate with you or your question?

You can look up the suggested themes, keywords, and interpretations {@book in this book|FDoMT|3} for each card or follow your own intuition for what the card means to you. Consider how what the card shows you might apply to the situation for which you are seeking clarity.
Beyond this simple way of using the cards to help you connect with your intuition, there are three other ways to use the colorful Overworld and monochrome Underworld to seek deeper meanings.

card.name: Balance
entries: Your mind suffers a wrenching alteration, causing your alignment to change. Lawful becomes chaotic, good becomes evil, and vice versa. If you are true neutral or unaligned, this card has no effect on you. Found only in decks of twenty-two or forty-four cards.

card.name: Comet
entries: If you single-handedly defeat the next hostile monster or group of monsters you encounter, you gain experience points enough to gain one level. Otherwise, this card has no effect. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Death
entries: This is the representation of an {@creature avatar of death|XDMG}, a creature summoned by the Skull card. If you are using this deck as a deck of many things, remove the Death card first. (See page 12 for the {@creature avatar of death|XDMG} stat block.)

card.name: Donjon
entries: You disappear and become entombed in a state of suspended animation in an extradimensional sphere. Everything you were wearing and carrying stays behind in the space you occupied when you disappeared. You remain imprisoned until you are found and removed from the sphere. You can't be located by any divination magic, but a {@spell wish} spell can reveal the location of your prison. You draw no more cards. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Euryale
entries: The card's medusa-like visage curses you. You take a -2 penalty on saving throws while cursed in this way. Only a god or the magic of The Fates card can end this curse.

card.name: Fates
entries: Reality's fabric unravels and spins anew, allowing you to avoid or erase one event as if it never happened. You can use the card's magic as soon as you draw the card or at any other time before you die. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Flames
entries: A powerful devil becomes your enemy. The devil seeks your ruin and plagues your life, savoring your suffering before attempting to slay you. This enmity lasts until either you or the devil dies.

card.name: Fool
entries: You lose 10,000 XP, discard this card, and draw from the deck again, counting both draws as one of your declared draws. If losing that much XP would cause you to lose a level, you instead lose an amount that leaves you with just enough XP to keep your level. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Gem
entries: Twenty-five pieces of jewelry worth 2,000 gp each or fifty gems worth 1,000 gp each appear at your feet.

card.name: Idiot
entries: Permanently reduce your Intelligence score by 1d4 + 1 (to a minimum score of 1). You can draw one additional card beyond your declared draws.

card.name: Jester
entries: You gain 10,000 XP, or you can draw two additional cards beyond your declared draws.

card.name: Key
entries: A rare or rarer magic weapon with which you are proficient appears in your hands. The GM chooses the weapon.

card.name: Knight
entries: You gain the service of a 4th-level fighter who appears in a space you choose within 30 feet of you. The fighter is of the same race as you and serves you loyally until death, believing the fates have drawn him or her to you. You control this character.

card.name: Moon
entries: You are granted the ability to cast the {@spell wish} spell {@dice 1d3} times.

card.name: Rogue
entries: A nonplayer character of the GM's choice becomes hostile toward you. The identity of your new enemy isn't known until the NPC or someone else reveals it. Nothing less than a {@spell wish} spell or divine intervention can end the NPC's hostility toward you.

card.name: Ruin
entries: All forms of wealth that you carry or own, other than magic items, are lost to you. Portable property vanishes. Businesses, buildings, and land you own are lost in a way that alters reality the least. Any documentation that proves you should own something lost to this card also disappears.

card.name: Skull
entries: You summon an {@creature avatar of death|XDMG}—a ghostly humanoid skeleton clad in a tattered black robe and carrying a spectral scythe. It appears in a space of the GM's choice within 10 feet of you and attacks you, warning all others that you must win the battle alone. The avatar fights until you die or it drops to 0 hit points, whereupon it disappears. If anyone tries to help you, the helper summons its own avatar of death. A creature slain by an avatar of death can't be restored to life.

card.name: Star
entries: Increase one of your Ability Scores by 2. The score can exceed 20 but can't exceed 24.

card.name: Sun
entries: You gain 50,000 XP, and a wondrous item (which the GM determines randomly) appears in your hands.

card.name: Talons
entries: Every magic item you wear or carry disinte-grates. Artifacts in your possession aren't destroyed but do vanish. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Throne
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Persuasion} skill, and you double your proficiency bonus on checks made with that skill. In addition, you gain rightful ownership of a small keep somewhere in the world. However, the keep is currently in the hands of monsters, which you must clear out before you can claim the keep as yours.

card.name: Vizier
entries: At any time you choose within one year of the drawing this card, you can ask a question in meditation and mentally receive a truthful answer to that question. Besides information, the answer helps you solve a puzzling problem or other dilemma. In other words, the knowledge comes with wisdom on how to apply it. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Void
entries: This card spells disaster. Your soul is drawn from your body and contained in an object in a place of the GM's choice. One or more powerful beings guard the place. While your soul is trapped in this way, your body is {@condition incapacitated}. A wish spell can't restore your soul, but the spell reveals the location of the object that holds it. You draw no more cards.

card.name: Balance
entries: Your mind suffers a wrenching alteration, causing one of your personality traits to invert. Bold becomes meek, polite becomes rude, and suchlike. You choose which trait is altered. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Comet
entries: From the moment you draw this card, you can't regain hit points or restore hit points to others. This effect only ends when you defeat a hostile monster or group of monsters with the help of your allies. You and each person who contributed to your victory gains one level. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Donjon
entries: You are thrown to another point in time chosen by the GM. You appear at a time and place determined by the GM. Everything you are wearing and carrying travels with you. All attempts to locate or contact you with divination magic fail, but a wish spell can reveal your location. You draw no more cards. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Euryale
entries: You permanently gain the ability to cast the {@spell globe of invulnerability} spell at will. You can choose any of your abilities as your spellcasting ability for the spell and you are not required to maintain concentration on it.

card.name: Fates
entries: You see the threads of futures that could be and spin them to your liking, allowing you to decide the outcome of an event that happens in the future. You can use the card's magic as soon as you draw the card or at any other time before you die. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Flames
entries: A powerful celestial becomes your enemy. The celestial is power-hungry and vain and considers itself a god in its own right. The celestial torments you to prove its divinity, toying with your fate until it tires of you and destroys you. This enmity lasts until either you or the celestial dies, or you can convince them to stop.

card.name: Fool
entries: You lose proficiency in a skill of your choice, discard this card, and draw from the deck again, counting both draws as one of your declared draws.

card.name: Gem
entries: Five different magic items of your choice appear at your feet. Each item can be of very rare or lower rarity.

card.name: Idiot
entries: The next time you roll a 1 on an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, this card grants you a gift: once, at any time before you die, you can treat any ability check, attack roll, or saving throw as a 20. This can be a roll made by yourself, an ally, or a foe. You can make this decision after seeing the result of the roll. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Jester
entries: You gain one 1st-level feature from any  other class you choose, or you can draw two additional  cards beyond your declared draws. This does not cause you  to gain a level and you are not required to meet any multiclassing requirements.

card.name: Key
entries: A key appears in your hands. You declare what it unlocks—it may be the key to a vault, a sealed  library, a secret box, or similar. The key works only once  on the single lock you specify. Once you have used the key, it crumbles to dust.

card.name: Knight
entries: A {@creature commoner} appears in a space you choose within 30 feet of you. The peasant is of the same race as you and is controlled by the GM. They beg for your help with a problem in their community. If you help them solve the problem, you earn the community's support and loyalty.

card.name: Moon
entries: You are granted the ability to cast the {@spell foresight} spell 1d4 + 2 times.

card.name: Rogue
entries: A duplicate of you is created in this world. They share your memories and experiences up to the point of you drawing this card. They want to destroy you and take your place. Nothing less than a {@spell wish} spell or divine intervention  can end the duplicate's hostility toward you. The GM controls this duplicate.

card.name: Ruin
entries: You lose all your memories of events that have occurred up until you drew this card. You retain your personality and statistics, but you do not recall your companions, NPCs, or any details of your life. Any documentation that proves you existed also vanishes.

card.name: Skull
entries: You summon an {@creature avatar of death|XDMG}. It appears adjacent to you and demands a great sacrifice. You choose the sacrifice and it must come from you alone. It could be blood, a memory, a treasured item, or similar. If satisfied, the avatar grants you the effects of the protection from evil and good spell permanently. If unsatisfied, it claims your soul and drags it to the land of the dead. Only divine intervention or a creature entering the land of the dead to retrieve your soul can restore you to life.

card.name: Star
entries: Choose two skills you are proficient in. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with these skills.

card.name: Sun
entries: Your Intelligence or Wisdom score increases by 2. The score can exceed 20 but can't exceed 24.  You also learn a secret that has a great impact on yourself or your world.

card.name: Talons
entries: A legendary magic item of the GM's choice appears in your possession. It belongs to a powerful NPC who knows you have their item and wants it back. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Throne
entries: You gain rightful leadership of an organization somewhere in the world. However, the organization's members are currently imprisoned by monsters, which you must clear out before you can claim the leadership of the organization. In addition, you gain proficiency in a skill relevant to the organization, and you double your proficiency bonus on checks made with it. The GM determines the skill.

card.name: Vizier
entries: At a time chosen by the GM within one year of drawing this card, an NPC approaches you and asks you to make an important decision. The decision is a significant and influential choice that has a great impact on the world and its people. This card grants you the power to enact your decision exactly as you want. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Void
entries: A soul contained in an object of the GM's choosing appears in front of you and the location of the soul's body is unknown to you. You must guard this soul by carrying the object on your person and preventing anyone else from taking the object. If you are separated from the object, your own soul is drawn from your body and contained in a similar object. If you reunite the soul with its body or a suitable alternative, you are freed from this burden.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Gorgoneia
entries: As a member of the Circle of the Gorgoneia, you follow the example of the legendary sisters Medusa, Euryale, and Stheno. The blood of these gorgons is said to hold the power to heal and harm, and your druidic practice reflects this duality. The gorgons have gifted you with the ability to transform into a living statue. Many Circle of the Gorgoneia druids spend their lives defending their wilderness homes against threats, and some take on gorgon-like features. The ignorant may call you a monster, but those who understand the gorgons' tale know you are a powerful protector of the things you hold dear.

entries.caption: Gorgon Features
rows: Flightless wings made from bronze sprout from your back.
You have tusks like a wild boar.
Your skin has patches of delicate, snake scales.
Your sharp fingernails are made of bronze.
Your glare chills the blood of any who dares meet your eye.
Your hair is a writing mass of living snakes.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you learn to channel the protective magic of your gorgon mentors. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of the Gorgoneia Spells table. Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

subclassFeature.name: Statuesque Wild Shape
entries: When you choose this circle at 2nd level, your skin hardens as you transform into a living statue. When you use your Wild Shape feature, you can expend a 1st level spell slot to add +1 to your AC and you deal an extra {@damage 1d6} magical bludgeoning damage on a hit. Additionally, you can't be {@condition petrified} and you have resistance to nonmagical bludgeoning, slashing, and piercing damage. These effects last while you remain in your Wild Shape or you use your Wild Shape Feature again.

At higher levels, when you expend a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the bonus to AC increases by 1, and your extra damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each spell slot level above 1st, to a maximum of 5th level spell slots.

subclassFeature.name: Apotropaic Magic
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can extend your protective abilities to others. As an action, you can touch another creature and expend a use of your Wild Shape feature to grant them ongoing protection. The creature gains temporary hit points equal to {@dice 2d10} + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier. While these temporary hit points last, the creature has resistance to nonmagical bludgeoning, slashing, and piercing damage and has advantage on Wisdom saving throws. Once you use this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Unbreakable
entries: At 10th level, while in your {@subclassFeature Statuesque Wild Shape|Druid||Gorgoneia|FablemakerDeck|2} you have resistance to all damage. Additionally, when a creature within 5 feet of you is hit with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to divert half of the attack's damage to yourself. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Petrifying Gaze
entries: By 14th level, the teachings of the gorgons have taught you a measure of their petrifying power. You learn the spell {@spell flesh to stone}. You always have this spell prepared, it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day, and it counts as a druid spell for you. You can cast this spell once per day without expending a spell slot. Additionally, when a creature you can see within range that can see you and you can see makes an attack against you, you can cast this spell as a reaction.

subclassFeature.name: Masked
entries: You are a masked rogue, a master of deception who uses magical masks to transform yourself into whoever you need to be to get the job done. Some masked rogues never allow themselves to be seen without a mask. That way, should they ever need to leave their underworld life behind them, they can take off the mask and melt back into the everyday world with their true identity intact. No matter the situation, you always know how to face it.

subclassFeature.name: Mysterious Masks
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain access to magical masks that change more than just your appearance. As a bonus action, you can don or switch a mask to gain its benefits.
Your Mask DC is equal to 8 + your proficiency + bonus your Charisma modifier. Choose two of the following mask options:
When you reach 7th, 13th, and 19th levels in this class, choose one additional mask.

subclassFeature.name: Deadly Masquerade
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your masked face confuses your enemies by making you appear to be one of their allies. You don't need advantage on the attack roll to use your Sneak Attack against a creature if you are within 5 feet of it, one of its allies is within 5 feet of you, and you don't have disadvantage on the attack roll. All the other rules for Sneak Attack still apply to you.

subclassFeature.name: A Hated Face
entries: At 9th level, you can call upon the magic of your masks to enrage an enemy and cloud their judgment. As a bonus action, you target a creature you can see within 60 feet of you to create an illusory figure of their most hated creature adjacent to it. The illusion shares your AC and counts as an enemy of the target when determin- ing Sneak Attack. It moves with the target and appears to be injured when hit, but it does not have any hit points. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw against your Mask DC. On a failed save, the target becomes enraged by your illusion and must use its Attack action against your illusion for 1 minute. An affected target can repeat its saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If the affected target hits your illusion on its turn, it makes this saving throw with advantage.
Once you have used this feature, you must complete a short or long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Death Masks
entries: Starting at 13th level, the faces of the dead become fodder for your morbid masquerade. When a humanoid creature dies within 30 feet of you, you can use your reaction to magically create a mask of their face. While wearing one of these masks, your appearance and voice change to match theirs as if you had cast disguise self. Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) checks made to see through your disguise must succeed against your Mask DC. You also know any basic information that they knew in life and any languages they knew, though you don't learn their deeply held secrets. For example, you would be able to recognize a creature's friends and move confidently around areas they knew in life, but you wouldn't learn the location of their hidden safe or any details of their plot to kill their rival.

You can have a number of these masks equal to your proficiency bonus at one time. If you create another mask after you have reached this limit, you must choose one of your existing masks to be destroyed.

subclassFeature.name: Face To Face
entries: Beginning at 17th level, the power of your masks allows you to transform yourself to make your foes face themselves. As a bonus action, you can target a creature within 60 feet of you that you can see. Your physical appearance and size transform to match the target's but you retain all of your other abilities and attributes. When you are transformed, your attacks against the target have advantage, and the target's attacks against you are made with disadvantage. Additionally, when you deal Sneak Attack Damage to the target or its allies, you deal an additional 3d6 psychic damage on a hit. Your transformation lasts until you dismiss it as a free action or become incapacitated. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1) and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: The Nemesis
entries: You have made a pact with a being who hates you with a divine passion. Your Nemesis is deeply invested in your eventual glorious failure, and they lift you up only so you have further to fall. The terms of your pact bind you both for now, and your ambition may outweigh your good sense. Whether you will snatch a final victory in defiance of your Patron or meet your downfall due to your own hubris remains to be seen.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Nemesis lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Spiteful Ambition
entries: Starting at 1st level, when you make a spell attack, you can choose to take a penalty equal to your proficiency bonus to the attack roll. If the attack hits you deal an extra {@dice 1d10} + your warlock level radiant damage. A target can only take this extra damage once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Overconfidence
entries: Beginning at 6th level, your faith in your own abilities pushes you to defy your Patron's taunts. You are immune to the {@condition frightened} condition. Additionally, you gain two resistances and one vulnerability from among the following damage types: acid, cold, fire, lightning, necrotic, and psychic.

subclassFeature.name: Doom's Ward
entries: From 10th level, the dark attention of your patron marks you as their particular prey. As an action, you can grant yourself temporary hit points equal to your warlock level + your Charisma modifier. These temporary hit points last for 10 minutes, and while you have them you gain the following benefits:

items: You have advantage on Intimidation checks.

Before a creature targets you with an attack it must first succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failure, it must choose another target for its attack. If there is no other suitable target in range, the creature loses its action. This feature has no effect on attacks that target an area of effect.

entries: Once you have used this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Not Yet
entries: Starting at 14th level, your patron has invested so much spite in you that they will only allow you a legendary death. When you drop to 0 hit points, you instead drop to 1 hit point and gain temporary hit points equal to your warlock level + your proficiency bonus. If you drop to 0 hit points again before you have completed a long rest, you have disadvantage on your death saving throws and if you die, you cannot be resurrected by any means. Additionally, the moment of your death releases an outpouring of triumphant hatred from your Patron, and all creatures within 60 feet of your body must make a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 8d10} radiant damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one.

optionalfeature.name: Crow Mask
entries: You can make {@skill Perception} checks as a bonus action, and you add your Charisma modifier to your {@skill Sleight of Hand} and {@skill Stealth} checks.

optionalfeature.name: Demon Mask
entries: When you hit a creature with your Sneak Attack, it must succeed on a Wisdom Saving throw against your Mask DC or become {@condition frightened} of you until the start of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Fox Mask
entries: While wearing this mask, you can cast the {@spell disguise self} spell. Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) checks made to see through your disguise must succeed against your Mask DC. Once you have used this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

optionalfeature.name: Noble Mask
entries: You have advantage on all Charisma checks and saving throws.

optionalfeature.name: Ogre Mask
entries: When making {@skill Athletics} checks or Grappling, you can use your Dexterity modifier instead of your Strength modifier.

optionalfeature.name: Spirit Mask
entries: While wearing this mask you can take the {@action Dodge} action as a bonus action.

data.name: Welcome to the Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things
entries: Welcome to the Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things, an oracle deck composed of two halves and inspired by cards from the 5e {@item deck of many things}. The first half of the deck is formed of the Overworld cards, showcasing vivid symbolism in brilliant color. The second monochrome half is made up of the Underworld cards. These black and white cards invite you to reexamine the cards' themes and dig deeper to find new answers to your questions.

The deck pairs the tradition of oracle card reading with the challenging themes of the {@item deck of many things}. In this guidebook, you'll find compelling questions called Seeds of Change to help guide your mind as you consult the cards.

Beautifully illustrated by Yoshi Yoshitani, the deck is also a fully functional {@item deck of many things} that can be used in your tabletop roleplaying games. The Underworld deck also has alternate rules for the {@item deck of many things}, with twenty-two new card effects that reflect each card's theme. The {@item deck of many things} is an infamous magic item, and its power to shift a game for the better or worse inspired the themes of risk and reward you'll find throughout this book. What card will you draw?

entries.name: USING OTHER DECKS WITH THIS GUIDEBOOK
entries: If you would like to use these rules with other physical versions of the {@item deck of many things}, cut the deck and rotate one-half of the cards. Then, shuffle the two piles together so that half the cards are upside down and will be drawn with their imagery inverted. When cards are drawn from the deck, interpret cards drawn upright as Overworld cards and those drawn reversed as Underworld cards.

data.name: How to Use the Deck as a 5e Magic Item
entries: The 5e {@item deck of many things} is a fantastic item with powerful magic. It can change your game in an instant, for better or worse. Each card drawn from the deck immediately impacts the character who draws from it, and in some cases, it can reshape reality itself.

You can use either the Overworld or Underworld half of the deck to represent this item in your games as a fun interactive tool for players. They can draw from the deck when they declare that their character will, or the Game Master (GM) can draw for them if you are playing online. The Overworld effects of the cards detailed in this booklet are the standard effects of the {@item deck of many things}.

However, the Fablemaker's {@item deck of many things} offers another way to play, bringing more risk and potentially more rewards than ever. The Underworld effects are an alternate version of the {@item deck of many things}. There are several ways to include these new effects in your game. You can choose to use only the Underworld effects of the cards, or you can flip a coin to determine whether the effect of a drawn card is the standard Overworld effect or the new Underworld effect. You can also shuffle both halves together and let the luck of the draw determine the effect by applying the effect matching the card drawn. For even more customization, you can select the cards you want from the Overworld and Underworld and combine them into your own unique {@item deck of many things}.

items: {@font BALANCE|Firdevs} ({@font {@card BALANCE|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card BALANCE|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font COMET|Firdevs} ({@font {@card COMET|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card COMET|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})
{@font {@card DEATH|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things|FablemakerDeck}|FirDevs}

{@font DONJON|Firdevs} ({@font {@card DONJON|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card DONJON|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font EURYALE|Firdevs} ({@font {@card EURYALE|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card EURYALE|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font FATES|Firdevs} ({@font {@card FATES|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card FATES|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font FLAMES|Firdevs} ({@font {@card FLAMES|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card FLAMES|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font FOOL|Firdevs} ({@font {@card FOOL|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card FOOL|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font GEM|Firdevs} ({@font {@card GEM|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card GEM|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font IDIOT|Firdevs} ({@font {@card IDIOT|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card IDIOT|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font JESTER|Firdevs} ({@font {@card JESTER|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card JESTER|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font KEY|Firdevs} ({@font {@card KEY|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card KEY|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font KNIGHT|Firdevs} ({@font {@card KNIGHT|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card KNIGHT|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font MOON|Firdevs} ({@font {@card MOON|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card MOON|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font ROGUE|Firdevs} ({@font {@card ROGUE|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card ROGUE|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font RUIN|Firdevs} ({@font {@card RUIN|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card RUIN|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font SKULL|Firdevs} ({@font {@card SKULL|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card SKULL|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font STAR|Firdevs} ({@font {@card STAR|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card STAR|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font SUN|Firdevs} ({@font {@card SUN|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card SUN|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font TALONS|Firdevs} ({@font {@card TALONS|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card TALONS|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font THRONE|Firdevs} ({@font {@card THRONE|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card THRONE|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font VIZIER|Firdevs} ({@font {@card VIZIER|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card VIZIER|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

{@font VOID|Firdevs} ({@font {@card VOID|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)|FablemakerDeck|O}|AGaramondProRegular}/({@font {@card VOID|Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Underworld)|FablemakerDeck|U}|AGaramondProRegular})

data.name: How to Use the Deck for Oracle Readings
entries: To consult the deck as an oracle, choose a problem, situation, or question in your life that you want to consider more deeply.
Shuffle both the Overworld and Underworld cards together and draw a card. Examine the imagery. How does it make you feel? Are there any symbols that resonate with you or your question?

You can look up the suggested themes, keywords, and interpretations in this book for each card or follow your own intuition for what the card means to you. Consider how what the card shows you might apply to the situation for which you are seeking clarity.
Beyond this simple way of using the cards to help you connect with your intuition, there are three other ways to use the colorful Overworld and monochrome Underworld to seek deeper meanings.

entries.name: Method One: Pairing the Cards
entries: This technique pairs the Overworld cards with the corresponding Underworld cards. Separate and shuffle just the Overworld cards as you contemplate your problem. Shuffling the deck requires no special technique because the purpose is to find the card that you are most drawn to, not to randomize the cards. When you feel you are done, regroup the cards into a facedown stack.

Draw a card from the deck. Next, find the corresponding card in the Underworld deck. What differences can you see between the two? How does the dark perspective of the monochrome card make you feel in comparison to the bright and colorful one? Which do you feel more drawn to?

The colorful Overworld cards can represent the face-value meanings of the symbolism, while the colorless Underworld cards can represent obscure, reversed, or subtler meanings. By drawing and comparing the two cards, you can find more than one perspective on your ques tion and perhaps an answer that balances both.

entries.name: Method Two: Dividing the Cards
entries: This technique allows you to mix and match the two halves to find two different aspects of your life to contemplate. Shuffle the Overworld and Underworld cards separately and compose your question. Draw one card from the Overworld and one card from the Underworld. Each card presents a different solution or perspective that can be read separately or together.

For example, you might ask, "What is the best way for me to help my friend who is struggling?" If you were to draw the Overworld Knight and the Underworld Vizier and read them separately, the Knight might suggest your friend needs you to actively support them, while the Vizier indicates that your friend needs advice. Read together these cards could suggest your friends need you to support a decision they have reached on their own.

entries.name: Method Three: Selecting a Card
entries: You can select a card that deals with themes appropriate to your situation. This method works best once you have made a connection with your deck. There is no need to shuffle; you can simply choose the card you want to consult from the deck face up. You can choose the same card from the Overworld and Underworld or select two themes to consult, taking each from a different half. See the Card Themes table for each card's central theme.

entries.name: Seeds of Change
entries: Seeds of Change are questions that explore the themes of the cards in more detail. The Overworld cards come with Seeds to address immediate and pressing issues, and the Underworld Seeds of Change pose questions to help you look beneath the surface with a new perspective.

When you draw a card, you can choose the Seeds of Change question that most resonates with you in the context of the problem you are trying to solve. You can also go through them one by one and consider them in turn, or you can roll a die to determine which one most needs your attention at random.

Remember to draw inspiration from the art on the card when you are reflecting on the Seeds. The art is as important as the guiding questions in the booklet. If you want to explore your situation further, draw another card and work through the Seeds in whichever way resonates most with you.

entries.name: {@font BALANCE|Firdevs}
entries: Balance is the great moderator of disagreements and encourages all parties to consider different perspectives. The central figure stands veiled, holding a sword and a set of scales. A white veil covers their face, symbolizing their commitment to look beyond what is familiar and consider new ideas without prejudice. The scales sit empty, awaiting input from different sides of the story. The figure's sword is drawn but remains at rest, which represents their readiness to act as well as their mercy and fairness. This card invites you to take a step back and think about viewpoints that you may not have considered before. The figure's raised wings and ready sword remind you that once a decision has been reached, action is the next step.

items: Have you weighed all sides of the issue and considered multiple viewpoints?
How would you feel if you were on the opposite side of the matter?
What emotions are influencing your perspective right now?
Are you seeing things as they are, or are you seeing things as you are?
Where can you find concrete knowledge to help you make a decision?
Are you taking the time and space to listen, or are you more focused on presenting your own opinions?
Is there something you must ignore so you can see more clearly without bias?
What are you currently balancing in your life, and are you treating these things fairly?
How have you formed your opinion on this matter?
Who in your life could you approach for their unique perspective?

entries.name: {@font COMET|Firdevs}
entries: The hero hurtles down, wreathed in flame. Wearing their gold helmet and holding their sword aloft, they descend and deliver a swift kick to their foe. They close their eyes, making the action look effortless, as their dramatic blaze of glory draws the viewer's gaze away from the hordes of monsters surrounding them . The hero wants their victory to shine in this moment, eclipsing any signs of struggle and concealing any weaknesses. They look valiant and radiant, but it's uncertain whether they'll be able to vanquish the other monsters on their own.

items: How does the reward for facing challenges alone differ from the reward for facing them with someone else?
What do you risk by asking for help?
Which is more enticing: solving the problem or looking good while solving it?
What advice would you give to someone you care about who was dealing with the same challenge?
How can you learn from the experience of solving this problem by yourself?
The seed of bravery is fear—what are you afraid of, and how can you face it?
What could you gain from asking for help?
Is it important to you that others see you solving the problem alone?
By focusing on this problem, what other problems are you ignoring?
When you succeed, how will you choose your next challenge?

entries.name: {@font DEATH|Firdevs}
entries: Death represents the struggle of self against self. Something within you may be holding you back. Endings are part of change for better and worse, and this card invites you to confront the aspects of yourself that you want to change honestly and compassionately. The figure depicted on this card is a part of you. Though it may look like one of your demons, it may, in fact, be a warning or a protector in disguise. It challenges you to seek resolution with a part of yourself that blocks a potential pathway to change and encourages you to consider whether or not this change will lead to positivity and growth. To prevail in this clash, all must be laid bare and self-deception cast aside. What you uncover beneath the figure's grisly mask may help you decide how to move forward.

items: What changes do you want for yourself?
What is still uncertain about the situation, and how do you feel about that uncertainty?
What feelings are you trying to ignore?
Think about an aspect of your life in which you feel stuck. What feelings emerge when you consider why you feel this way?
What feelings would you rather turn away from than confront?
What are the obstacles to the change you want?
Is your uncertainty coming from a fear of change itself?
How can you be more honest with yourself?
What do you need to move forward?
What is one way that you could honor your feelings about a difficult situation?

entries.name: {@font DONJON|Firdevs}
entries: The Donjon confines the mind and the heart, causing us to with draw from others and into ourselves. While spending time alone can be beneficial, this card represents isolation forced upon us either by outside forces or by our own fears. Though the prison's bars are wide enough to allow escape, some force keeps these spirits trapped. Though each soul despairs separately, they all suffer in common. An ominous figure, the jailer is not as powerful as it appears; it is bound to this place by its own chains. We can't always choose our circumstances, but we can exercise what power we have to reach out to those suffering alongside us. Perhaps one day, we will find what we need to escape our confinement.

items: In what ways do you feel trapped or cut off from others?
Are you setting boundaries to honor your feelings, or are you putting up walls to keep people away?
What would be the worst outcome of your situation? Is this realistic?
How could sharing your vulnerabilities with others change your situation?
How can you adjust your attitude to circumstances beyond your control?
How can you connect to others?
Is there someone you can safely reach out to for help?
What do you like most about your current situation?
Are there others in a similar situation you can relate to?
Consider the obstacles in your way—are they real or imagined?

entries.name: {@font EURYALE|Firdevs}
entries: The gorgon sits on a petrified kneeling figure, flanked by two other stone humans. She shrugs as though this situation is a regular occurrence for her. The card shows the aftermath of events and leaves the rest of the story untold: why did the humans come to the gorgon's lair, and what did they do to transgress her boundar ies? Many popular depictions of gorgons frame them as aggressors, but modern interpretations suggest that they used their powers in self-defense when a threat emerged. Sometimes, following through with the consequences you promised is necessary to assert and protect yourself.

items: How would setting and enforcing your boundaries affect your situation?
What expectations do you contend with when you feel pressured?
What are you afraid will happen if you set a boundary?
Consider the natural consequences of your possible courses of action—are you willing to accept them?
Have people overstepped your boundaries in the past? How can you create new boundaries based on what you learned?
What is preventing you from setting and enforcing your boundaries?
What is the source of the expectations you face?
When you make a promise, how do you plan to keep it? What would make you break it?
How can you better respect the boundaries other people set?
Are you putting time and thought into what matters to you or what you think matters to others?

entries.name: {@font FATES|Firdevs}

entries: {@font CIRCUMSTANCE, CHANGE, THE PAST, RELATIONSHIPS, TRANSFORMATION|AGaramondProRegular}
{@font COLLABORATION, DIVERGENCE, ENTANGLEMENT, THE FUTURE, REVOLUTION|AGaramondProRegular}

These three women gather to determine and oversee the destiny of mortals. Here, the Fates prepare to erase an event from the past, represented by cutting the thread. All three participate in the ritual, demonstrating that they are connected within the weave of time. The Fate about to cut the thread appears confident that even though this break with the past will leave its mark, she will not need to repair the fabric alone. Leaves fall from her headpiece as the wind blows back her hair. These same leaves cloak the youngest Fate, who represents our past selves and are absent from the eldest Fate, who represents our future selves. For us, the past is inflexible, but the future is not. Though change involves letting go of things we cannot alter about the past, it does not mean that the past is not still with us. The pink of the elder Fate's cloak mirrors the younger Fates's blossoms, though the color has become more nuanced with age. We can choose what to take with us into the future and what to leave behind, confident that the connections we choose to keep will foster growth and wisdom.

items: How have your past experiences shaped you?
If you could travel through time, what would you say to your past self?
What event in your past are you holding on to?
What have you learned from relationships that have ended?
Is there something about yourself you'd like to change?
What would you like to experience in the future?
Is there anyone with more experience than you who could give you advice?
How can your past experiences help you grow into who you want to be?
What kind of connections would you like to make in the future?
What would it mean to take the first step toward a change?

entries.name: {@font FLAMES|Firdevs}

entries: {@font EXPLOITATION, HARM, GRIEVANCE, POWER IMBALANCE, MISUNDERSTANDING|AGaramondProRegular}

Flames is the card of injustice, representing circumstances in which power is used to cause suffering. These systems of harm and oppression are symbolized by a giant flame-wreathed snake, its vast and tangled body reflecting the complex and interconnected legacy of injustices borne out over the ages. The fire that engulfs it demonstrates not only the harm that comes from the improper use of power but also how oppressive structures are ultimately self consuming. Power is never stable, and those who hold it would be wise to exercise it fairly, lest it become their ruin. A single firefly, bathed in resplendent light, streaks away from the monstrosity. Its flight is an act of defiance against the serpent's will, but the outcome of its escape is unclear. We may become aware of injustice, but this alone is not enough. We must strive to challenge and dismantle the unjust power structures that influence our lives, or the Flames will consume us.

items: In which areas of your life do you feel disempowered?
In what ways have you hurt others in a less powerful position, however unintentionally?
How can you align your power with your values?
When you see injustice, how do you want to react? Does this differ from how you do act?
What part of our interconnected world can you improve close to home?
What obstacles are in your way?
What can you do to make amends for the harm you have caused intentionally or not?
How can you challenge your biases?
In what ways can you care for yourself when faced with injustice?
How can you kindle hope in yourself and others?

entries.name: {@font FOOL|Firdevs}
entries: The Fool plummets from the sky into a chasm as the sun's arrows pierce their wings. Plans fail, circumstances change, and the unexpected occurs without warning. The figure brings to mind the mythic character of Icarus, who flew too close to the sun. They warn us of the dangers of overconfidence and disregarding the wisdom of others.

Though the Fool's situation appears dire, things may not be as hopeless as they seem. The arrows that streak through them point the way to many possible futures. What we at first perceive as failure can in fact be the gateway to something new, if only we are wise enough to recognize it. By accepting things as they are and not as we fear them to be, we can clearly listen to the parts of ourselves that will lead us to safety. The Fool's expression is one of surprise, not despair. What they glimpse in the space between the rocks may in fact be a path to freedom.

items: What is a recent setback you've experienced?
Who or what are you ignoring for the sake of your pride?
Who's advice do you value and why?
Do you feel safe to fail?
What circumstances are out of your control?
Are you ready to accept the fallout of your choices, both good and bad?
What isn't working, and how could you address it?
What could you do to place more trust in yourself?
What would you need to feel safe to make mistakes?
How do you want to react to things beyond your control?

entries.name: {@font GEM|Firdevs}
entries: The central figure in this card is covered in golden jewelry and seated upon a rock in a cave filled with riches. Here, sequestered from the world, he is content among his gains, basking in the splen dor of his good fortune. Fortune is fleeting, and this card reminds us to allow ourselves enjoyment in these moments as they find us.

The cave that houses the figure is a liminal space of reflection and self-assessment. Within, we can consolidate our gains, pause, and consider what comes next. We can't stay here forever. Fortunes change. The mouth of the cave looms behind the figure's head like the jaws of a great beast, and even the rock upon which he sits could be a sleeping dragon. For now, we have the good fortune to gather our strength before we embark on our next adventure.

items: What are some things in your life you feel fortunate for?
What do you wish to cultivate in the future?
Are you distinguishing between things you need and things you want?
What brings you satisfaction and how can you seek it in relation to your situation?
How could you better prepare for an uncertain future?
What qualities do you appreciate in others, and how can you cultivate these in yourself?
How can you revel in this moment?
Is the difference between wanting something and needing it important to you?
If your fortunes were to change for the worse, what could you rely on to help you through it?
What's a step you could take today that would make your future feel more secure?

entries.name: {@font IDIOT|Firdevs}
entries: The sphinx spreads her wings in triumph with a forepaw resting on the cracked helmet of a defeated challenger. The challenger's weap ons lie below the helmet, shield dented and sword chipped. Clearly, the challenger thought they were ready to outwit or fight the sphinx, but she outmatched them. It is unknown what, if anything, the chal lenger did to prepare for combat or whether they thought the battle would be easy. Either way, it was a fight they couldn't win.

Some challenges are too great to face right now, which is a hard lesson to learn. But just because it's not the right time to take up the challenge doesn't mean that you'll never do it; it just means that you'll be in a better position to try at a more opportune time.

items: What challenges are you eager to face?
Is there any aspect of your life you regard with too much pride?
What can you do to prepare for your next challenge?
Is the problem you are facing one you must face now?
What can your past failures teach you about a current difficulty?
Is the situation you find yourself in one that could benefit from decisive action?
Where could you gain new information that you haven't considered yet?
Is there something you've been putting off because it seems difficult?
Can you solve your problem with lateral thinking rather than head on?
If you make a mistake, how will you learn from it?

entries.name: {@font JESTER|Firdevs}
entries: The Jester card signals a moment of wild opportunity, a chance that could slip through your fingers if not grasped. The twin Jesters depicted on this card are weal and woe, joy and sadness, laughter and tears. They offer a chance to spin the wheel of fate. Where there is reward, there is often risk, and this opportunity could lead to a disaster as easily as to a blessing. It is up to you whether you feel empowered to take the risk. The Jesters do not judge. Within the cosmic void, all are free to spin the wheel as long as they are pre pared to live with the consequences. The wheel shines, beckoning your hand, but you can still choose to reject its lure. Actions cannot be undone, and the choice to be open to risk is as meaningful as the choice to walk away from it. It is up to you to decide whether or not to spin the wheel.

items: What do you risk by accepting this opportunity?
Is this opportunity really now or never?
Have you been faced with a similar choice before?
What would it mean to walk away this situation?
Do you feel ready to accept the possibility of failure?
Is accepting an opportunity worth the potential reward?
What could you gain from waiting?
Do you feel your fate will be determined more by luck or by your own skill? How can you tip the balance one way or the other?
Is there something you can do now with no preparation that will help?
What are you willing to risk for the reward you desire?

entries.name: {@font KEY|Firdevs}
entries: The blacksmith forges a golden key in the core of her workshop. Amidst the unbearable heat, she takes a moment to focus and re-center herself as she raises her hammer for one final strike. Though the flames surround her, they do not burn her, and her determination helps her finish the task at hand. She knows that soon she can leave the forge and take her creation with her, having made what she needs to move forward. The key glows brighter than the flames, symbolizing the ability to outshine and overpower adversity. Though you may not have a magic weapon at your side, there are other ways to forge the key you need.

items: What do you need at this moment?
What resources do you have at your disposal?
What motivates you to keep going?
What about this situation is difficult?
How can you bring the situation you face to a satisfying conclusion?
How can you make what you need yourself?
How can you make the best use of your resources?
How can reignite your motivations when you are thinking of giving up?
What helps you focus, and how can you apply that to this problem?
When can you make time for yourself to rest?

entries.name: {@font KNIGHT|Firdevs}
entries: The Knight is a stalwart ally, ever ready to aid a soul in need. Clad in armor, they stand against those who wield power unjustly or cause harm. The sun blazes behind them, banishing darkness and casting their visage in shadow. The Knight can be anyone: a friend, a lover, a parent, a sibling, or a stranger. The Knight can even be you. The sword they wield is the emblem of the cause they cham pion. The golden wings on its cross guard represent swiftness and progress, and the sun that encircles its blade symbolizes the absence of ignorance. The Knight's armor protects them but does not let us see their face. What keeps us safe can also become a barrier between us. Sometimes, we need a protector, and at others, it falls to us to pick up the sword for the sake of an ally. When we gird ourselves with compassion and wield a worthy cause, we learn how to stand together against malice and cruelty.

items: Who in your life is  need of support?
Do you see yourself as a protector or in need of protection? What could you gain by switching roles?
Can you ask for the support you need?
Have you lost touch with someone in your life?
Is there someone in your life you feel you could confide in?
In what tangible ways can you show up for your friends?
Is there a balance of give and take in your relationships with others?
What is one way you could practice self-advocacy?
What would it mean to reconnect with someone you've drifted from?
How can you engage with your wider community?

entries.name: {@font MOON|Firdevs}
entries: The Moon watches like a giant eye as the central figure cradles a fish in a bubble. It controls the ebb and flow of the sea, which is fickle, but its tides are predictable. The tides swirl around the moon, rep resenting the endless and contradictory possibilities. Though there may be things you want with all your heart, wishing alone won't make it real.

When the mundanities of daily life become boring, or when you are caught off guard by an unpleasant surprise, there's little harm in escaping to your dreams for a while. But be careful not to languish there too long. The light of the Moon is beautiful, but it is only a reflection of sunlight. Remember to wake up and enjoy reality too.

items: What is something relaxing that you can do for yourself today?
What is distracting you from your goal?
What is the most fantastical outcome you can imagine for your situation?
What truly brings you joy? How can you find more time for it?
Is there something new you want to try?
What relaxing activity can you plan as a reward for your efforts now?
Have you been lying to yourself or others? How can you make amends?
Are there any fictional characters you admire? How can you emulate their positive traits?
Can you trick yourself into doing something boring but important?
What have you been overindulging in? How can you find moderation in your life?

entries.name: {@font ROGUE|Firdevs}
entries: The masked rogue perches on a ledge overlooking a city at night, brandishing an ornate dagger. They raise their other hand to adjust their fox-like face covering or perhaps to muffle the sound of their laughter. Though the Rogue is clad in black, their bright red-and gold cloak suggests they want to be seen so their enemy knows they are hostile. Their mask hides their expression, preventing the viewer from discerning their motivations or feelings. We all wear a mask of a kind, and it's not possible to fully know the inner worlds of oth ers. Some people may dislike you for no apparent reason or despite your best efforts.

From their perch, the Rogue reminds us that some solutions require us to step outside our bounds, whether set by ourselves or others. Not all rules are just, and sometimes we must be a little roguish or accept being disliked to do what's right.

items: Is anyone working against you in this situation? If so, how can you outwit them?
Are you willing to make enemies if it means getting what you want?
What do you want to show to the world, and what do you want to hide?
What do you hate, and how do you want to improve it?
Are you doing the normal, expected thing in this situation?
Is there an area of your life that would benefit from a shake up?
Experience breeds confidence—how can you get more experience to help you grow?
Is there an unconventional solution you have been reluctant to persue?
If you have done something wrong, how can you ensure you never do it again?
Is there an unexpected way to approach your problem?

entries.name: {@font RUIN|Firdevs}
entries: All buildings and structures are ablaze in the Ruin card, with one tower standing high above the rest. The smoke and flames dominate the image and eclipse the sky, representing the all-consuming nature of the tragedy. Beneath, a kneeling figure weeps, the cold colors of their sorrow bleeding into the background. Sometimes, it's simply not possible to glean positives from disaster, and there are no lessons to be found in the ashes of suffering. This card asks us to consider the grief of losing everything. In the aftermath of such a profound loss, where do you go?

Still, Ruin does not have to be completely bleak. Despite their sor row, the weeping figure stands out brightly against the darkness that surrounds them. Though the transformation can be painful, it can be beneficial to let go of things that are holding us back.

items: What do you need to help you accept what you have lost?
What would help you feel safe and secure in this situation?
Is there anyone in your life who is suffering? What support can you offer them?
What can you do to hold onto the feeling of comfort?
If you lost everything and had to start again, what kind of life would you want to build for yourself?
What can you give up to lighten your burden?
How can you break out of the framework of expectations imposed on you by others?
Is there something from your past that is holding you back? Can you find a way to release its hold on you?
Is there a way to break down what you're facing into smaller, more manageable pieces?
What structures in your life could be torn down and rebuilt for the better?

entries.name: {@font SKULL|Firdevs}
entries: The card of sacrifice, the Skull, is the emblem of a challenge that asks you to look inward and make a choice only you can make. The eyes of the Skull are set upon you, its morbid gaze empty. You have the power to decide which course to take, but you may need to sacrifice your own comfort and meet the expectations placed upon you. Value the counsel of others, but know that what comes next is up to you. It may be tempting to allow another to make your decisions for you, but the challenge issued by the Skull demands that you trust in yourself enough to choose a course of action.

items: What would you like to accomplish?
What do you need to sacrifice to fulfill your desire?
How can you step up and lead the way?
What would make you feel more confident about your decision?
Who do you trust and not trust to help you with your situation?
How would accomplishing your goal affect your life and the lives of those close to you?
Are you acting in response to circumstances or on your own initiative?
Is there anyone whose counsel you trust in this matter?
What would it mean to surrender your control over this situation?
Is there an issue in the past that you feel the need to make up for now? How would you approach your current situation without that influence?

entries.name: {@font STAR|Firdevs}
entries: Adorned in a luxurious fur cape, the Star takes center stage on this card. Soft clouds swirl in the background as glitter falls around him, matching his makeup. He holds magic energy in each hand, and there is no doubt that he is powerful and experienced. In the glitter ing drama of a final performance, it's easy to overlook the hard work that goes into building toward opening night. Remember that even the glamorous Star got his start as a stagehand and worked his way up to the spotlight, where others now see him. Although hard work takes place behind the scenes, the reward is your accomplishments shining publicly.

items: What are your long-term career goals?
What skills do you want to learn or improve upon?
Who can help you cultivate these skills?
What opportunities can you make for yourself in your chosen field?
What professional mistakes have you made, and what have you learned from them?
What does your existing experience tell you about your current problem?
Is there any skill you haven't yet explored that could help you?
What can you share with others about what you have already learned?
How can you accept that progress takes time?
What small habits could help you build toward your larger goal?

entries.name: {@font SUN|Firdevs}
entries: The central figure flies high into the sky on four feathered wings. Adorned with gold halo-like jewelry and makeup, she is resplendent in the Sun's light. She cradles a golden box in her left hand and holds her right above it in a reverent gesture. What rests within the box is known only to her. Even though she treasures her secret prize, the light from the Sun behind her reaches with outstretched hands, uplifting and inspiring others. She has earned the reward for her hard work, but when she opens the box, she will surely share its contents.

items: What have you achieved that you'd like to celebrate?
Do you have any accomplishments that you are downplaying or minimizing?
How can you use your accomplishments to help others?
Who or what inspires you? Can they motivate you now?
Is there anything holding you back from enjoying your accomplishments?
What would your ideal celebration of your success look like?
What is stopping you from celebrating yourself?
Is there something you can keep to yourself as a personal treasure or source of inner confidence?
How could you be a source of inspiration for others?
How can you claim more agency over the situation?

entries.name: {@font TALONS|Firdevs}
entries: The harpy streaks down through a burning sky, chasing an ornate pearl necklace. Despite the dangers, she risks her life for the precious object, her Talons outstretched to grasp it. The Talons are our desires, gripping us and convincing us to hold on to treasures even when they cause us pain. Desire compels us to fear loss, and in turn to hold more tightly to that which we cherish. Yet the tighter we grip a treasure, the more we risk shattering it in our grasp. The harpy's eyes are closed, and the expression on her face is one of resignation, but her talons have not yet closed on the necklace. Not all desires lead to joy. While there are times when we must resign ourselves to hardship to retain what we hold dear, there is wisdom in knowing when to let go. We need not chase our desires to our ruin. We can still abandon the pursuit if we choose.

items: What do you most desire?
What is the reason you are chasing after your goal?
What is most precious to you at this moment?
How would letting go of something you've been holding onto tightly change your situation?
Is your desire hurting you or helping you grow?
If you were to obtain what you most desire, what do you think would change?
What would you give up to achieve your desire?
How would you feel if you lost what is most precious to you?
What is unique about this situation, and how can you best seize it?
How would moderating your sense of need affect the situation?

entries.name: {@font THRONE|Firdevs}

entries: {@font BOUNTY, MASTERY, PROGRESS, SUCCESS, VALUE, WORK|AGaramondProRegular}

The promise of greatness takes center stage here, as the crown's radiance and the golden Throne's splendor invite you to ascend the cloth-covered steps and claim your rightful place. The light from these two symbols of power outshines the monsters that lurk behind them, drawing your attention toward the prize and away from the threat. The monsters grasp the throne and hover in front of it, demonstrating their intent to contest your claim. The lure of power and glory is great, but they can bring new difficulties.

items: Can you separate what is in your control from what is outside it?
Is there anything holding you back from acting in line with your values?
Is there a chance that you're underestimating the difficulty of the challenge?
Is there something frustrating your progress? How can you combat it?
Is there more than one path to the success you seek?
What do you need to achieve your goal that you are currently missing?
Are there any obstacles you are overlooking?
Have you been enticed and dazzled by a prize and how can you broaden your point of view beyond it?
Once you have achieved your goal, how will you share you success with others?
Is there anyone you can talk to who can help you determine if your expectations are realistic?

entries.name: {@font VIZIER|Firdevs}
entries: A gentle breeze wafts the scent of incense through the Vizier's med itative space. The moon and stars shine softly through the chiffon curtains. The Vizier crosses her legs, closes her eyes, and puts her hands together as she waits for clarity. While meditating, the Vizier smiles softly to herself, comfortable in the calm environment she has created. She seeks knowledge, but she knows she already has the answer—it's just a matter of locating it within herself and under standing how to act on it. This card reminds us that we can often find the answers we seek in quiet moments of solitude and reflection. The Vizier offers us her counsel and the wisdom she has gained if we are prepared to listen.

items: When you sit in silence, what do you hear within?
Letting your thoughts come and go without instant judgment, can you find clarity?
What new questions can you ask yourself about your problem?
Have other people faced a similar problem, and what can you learn from them?
What inner wisdom do you already have that you are struggling to apply?
What do you need to create a relaxing environment?
What can you do to make time for contemplation in your daily routine?
What would be the most encouraging thing someone could say to you as you face this situation?
Is there someone you can look to for guidance or inspiration on approaching your problem?
What is the first step to acting on your convictions?

entries.name: {@font VOID|Firdevs}
entries: In this card, gold chains pierce the soul, which is symbolized by the bright, winged heart in the center. Its owner stands behind it, their face lifeless and their expression vacant. They blend in with the Void around them, all but consumed by the swirling vortex. Even so, the trapped soul's light shines with determination, illuminating the rest of the card from its central position. Though four chains puncture the soul, only three sites of entry are bleeding, represent ing the soul's tenacity and resilience. The restraints hurt, but the soul doesn't break, for it knows that its chains can be released and it will be free one day.

items: What is your personal Void, the place where you feel trapped?
What aspects of yourself are locked away?
What is keeping you from living openly and freely?
Who benefits or suffers from you keeping parts of yourself hidden?
How have you shown resilience in the past, and how can you restore yourself afterward?
Is there a place, person, or thing that can bring you out of your personal Void?
Who is the person you imagine yourself as at the end of this?
What would it mean to unlock the hidden aspects of yourself?
How would you like to respond when someone shares their secrets with you?
How is this situation making you feel trapped or stuck? What would breaking free of it look like?
